cs351.core

Class Actor

  • java.lang.Object
    • cs351.core.Actor
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    FloorCeilingTile, Player, Wall, Zombie

    public abstract class Actor
extends java.lang.Object
    The Actor class represents any object that can be added to the game and updated each frame. It can be used to represent both moving and non-moving objects. The Engine will guarantee that the update function for each Actor will be called at most once per frame unless the shouldUpdate boolean is set to false (this can be done for something like a wall that never needs to move/be updated but still needs to be drawn).
    Author:
    Justin Hall

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Actor.UpdateResult
      UpdateResult contains a few different enum values that each Actor can use to tell the Engine how the update went.

      • update

        public abstract Actor.UpdateResult update(Engine engine,
                                          double deltaSeconds)
        Updates the Actor. The Engine guarantees that this function will be called at most once per frame for all existing Actors. This is also where the object should perform animation steps.
        Parameters:
        engine - reference to the Engine that is performing the frame update - can be used for Engine callbacks
        deltaSeconds - the number of seconds that have gone by since the last frame (can be used for animation, movement, etc.)
        Returns:
        result of the update - tells the Engine if it needs to do anything special (end the game, etc.)

      • collided

        public abstract void collided(Engine engine,
                              Actor actor)
        When the Engine detects a collision between two actors (player and wall, wall and zombie, etc.) it will generate collision events for all Actors involved. For example, if a wall and a zombie collided, the wall object would get a reference to the zombie, and the zombie would get a reference to the wall. The only thing that Actors don't have to deal with is offsetting themselves because of a collision. If two objects collide the Engine will push each of them (unless one of the Actors is static) away from each other.
        Parameters:
        engine - reference to the Engine that is performing the frame update - can be used for Engine callbacks
        actor - reference to the Actor object that collided with this object

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Let's the actor know that it is now pending destruction and should free up now-invalid references.

      • isPartOfFloor

        public boolean isPartOfFloor()
        The renderer will use this function to figure out whether the tile is part of the floor so it can draw it properly.
        Returns:
        true if it is part of the floor and false if not

      • shouldUpdate

        public boolean shouldUpdate()
        Checks to see if the given Actor needs to be updated every frame.
        Returns:
        true if it should update every frame and false if not

      • isStatic

        public boolean isStatic()
        The Engine uses this to figure out how to offset objects when they collide with each other. If one of the objects returns true when isStatic() is called, that object won't be pushed away from the other object at all.
        Returns:
        true if the object should not move and false if it should

      • noClipActive

        public boolean noClipActive()
        This is used as a flag during the Engine's collision detection routine. If no-clip is active it will let the Actor walk through anything but the floor.
        Returns:
        true if no-clip is active and false if not

      • setNoClip

        public void setNoClip(boolean value)
        Sets the value of no clip for the actor.
        Parameters:
        value - true if active (can phase through game objects) and false if not
